posts.cooked:
So lately I have been messaging a lot in group chats and one thing I have noticed is when my participants have read receipts enabled & they both read the message, I can‚Äôt tell who has read what when they open it without going into each users individual message status. It also only shows up as a default color of Gray with a single status indicator, which brings me here.

I propose a feature to bind whatever custom color you have for that contact as their read receipt color, so it makes it very easy to track who read what in a group chat. Of course, this would also require the developers to create multiple read receipt response indicators below the messages for each contact. However, I believe that this would definitely make the communication flow a lot better since all participants will instantly know who read what and conversely who hasn‚Äôt.

What do you think?

link_counts.title: Make message details (including who has read a group message) easier to find
Read receipt status based on @mentioned users
Please add a more detailed sent/delivered indicator for group chats
Different icon for read-by-all than read-by-at-least-one in group chats

posts.cooked: As an example of one way to implement this, the way Facebook Messenger does it is to put the profile icon of each user in a row under the last message that was read by them.
That sounds like a great idea, but I believe that would be best suited as an option along with the color coded read response indicator.

RequestForChange:

I have been messaging a lot in group chats‚Ä¶
I can‚Äôt tell who has read what‚Ä¶ and conversely who hasn‚Äôt.

‚Ä¶create multiple read-receipt [received] indicators
below the [groupchat] messages,
[one indicator] for each contact‚Ä¶
bind whatever custom color you have for that contact
as their read-receipt [received] color‚Ä¶

Very cool idea, yes. Groupchats tend to be small, but profile-pictures tend to be large and bulky. So the facebook-style approach is fine on a desktop-sized screen, or even a laptop-sized screen, but painfully bulky on a smartphone-sized display.

Colors are small though‚Ä¶ you can make a small square or rectangular image, which looks vaguely like a domino-like-pattern, with the dots colored to match your contacts, and the number of domino-dots corresponding to however many people are in the groupchat.

This can be quite regularized: each person in the groupchat, would have a ‚Äúposition on the domino‚Äù governed by the order in which they joined the groupchat in question, by default. As the groupchat grows in size, additional color-coded dots/people would appear on the domino, in a regular fill-pattern. As people clicked LeaveGroup from time to time, their dot-location would become ‚Äúvacant‚Äù ‚Ä¶ but to avoid shifting everything around, other people remaining in the groupchat would not shift into that vacant-dot-area. Eventually the groupchat would be large enough, you would have TWO domino-shapes in the metadata-area of each chat-bubble, etc. Here is a 5-person group:

  • Smaller groupchats remain cozy.
    SAT 1:23 PM   ‚öÑ 1/4 ()()

Here is a 10-person groupchat:

  • More dots, but still easy to grok.
    SAT 1:23 PM   üÅô 2/9 ()()

Versus the 40-person groupchat:

  • How big is our groupchat, nowadays?
    SAT 1:23 PM  üÅôüÇãüÇãüÇã 33/39 ()()

Once you get large enough, for space-reasons the color-dot-dominos need to be elided, and just numerals remain visible to indicate the readership-percentage.

  • Now this is a massive groupchat.
    SAT 1:23 PM   ~444/555 ()()

Somewhat-related feature-request, about adding the numerals related to the groupchat-read-receipt success-fraction, Show footers (time, delivery check mark, read check mark) for every message - #3 by 5_c_d ‚Ä¶and separately, feature-request about adding the groupchat-size-numerals to the send-message-button, Easy mixup of personal and group conversations leaks sensitive information - #3 by 5_c_d so that you can tell before you send whether 555 people, or 5 people, or just one person, will the the recipient of your message.

link_counts.title: Show footers (time, delivery check mark, read check mark) for every message
Easy mixup of personal and group conversations leaks sensitive information
Show delivery/read receipts only when all participants have received/read the message

posts.cooked:
5_c_d:

profile-pictures tend to be large and bulky. So the facebook-style approach is fine on a desktop-sized screen, or even a laptop-sized screen, but painfully bulky on a smartphone-sized display.

Not really. The profile pictures are sized down into pretty small indicator circles; about the size of the circles in Signal‚Äôs read receipt icons actually. It‚Äôs small, but you can still distinguish between them.

The problem with colors in current Signal is that you have a very limited number available, so they would need to expand that list first. Also, single colors get more difficult to tell apart when you have a lot of people.

Herohtar:

Not really.

It just depends on the size of the groupchat. Certainly, for five people, or even ten people, having a little row of thumbnail-avatar-pics would be ‚Äúsmall enough‚Äù for the UI.

But I think once you get to a couple dozen people in the groupchat even thumbnail-avatar-pics would get real annoying real quick, especially if there is heavy traffic of short one-liner messages, because your read-receipt-avatars will no longer fit on a single metadata-row. And with my favorite 99-member groupchat, even domino-things become unwieldy.

My preference would be to use positional-color-coded-domino-indicators in the chat-bubble, but then if the dominos of a specific message were tapped with a finger, a modal popup would appear that showed ‚Äúbig dominos‚Äù where each domino-dot was the avatar-picture of the person. After closing the modal, the dominos would ‚Äúcollapse back down‚Äù to the colorized version. It is hard to explain in words, I‚Äôll try to work up some simulated screenshots at some point, or a proof-of-concept. But perhaps this makes enough sense as-is. Longpressing and opening the message-details would also be able to use the ‚Äúbig dominos‚Äù perhaps‚Ä¶ but the current way it is done with rows-n-columns is probably fine (though I wish it was sortable and had user-controllable position for each of the groupchat membership).

Herohtar:

very limited number available, so they would need to expand that list ‚Ä¶ single colors get more difficult to tell apart when you have a lot of people

Yes, for the little-domino thing to work, those are the key problems. But I think the little-domino thing will only work with a limited set of easy-to-distinguish-from-each-other-colors in the overall palette ‚Ä¶ which is what signalapp has right now, kinda sorta anyways. If we add colors, that makes the little-dominos less useful, because it becomes increasingly hard to distinguish pale-green#3 from very-pale-green#4. But you are correct that the little-dominos are not perfect.

I just think they are better than what we have now, which is just, unfilled checkmarks when nobody has returned a read-receipt, and then, filled checkmarks when any single other groupchat member has returned a read-receipt (but no way to tell who it was and no way to tell how many have yet to return a read-receipt). The idea of the NN/MM numerals is to solve the problem of ‚Äúhow many got it so far‚Äù and the idea of the little-dominos / big-dominos / little-faces / similar schemes, is to solve the problem of ‚Äúwho got it so far‚Äù. Little-faces gives a better answer to ‚Äúwho‚Äù but requires more screen-real-estate, which means it only works well up to a certain size of groupchat. Little-dominoes gives a worse answer to ‚Äúwho‚Äù but works well up to a much bigger size of groupchat (though not hundreds of people methinks).

I suppose as a reply all, I could maybe make a suggestion that the icon for the read receipt [received] could also contain the original initials displayed in the contact list. Sometimes this includes a full name(which means 2 characters for their initials in the userlist icon), which gives a greater variable multiplier for possible combinations of letters/colors.

This would easily close the gap for the amount of combinations you‚Äôd need to fill even for large group chats(currently 12 possible colors, with a minimum variable of 26 characters, for a total of 312 possible combinations. And that is just a single character multiplier - as you know that number is WAY higher with 2 character combinations).

With that said, I actually don‚Äôt know how large signal group chats are, so if someone could let me know i‚Äôd probably be able to progress this idea with further modifications.

As an added bonus, this keeps the simplicity to a natural minimum so that it doesn‚Äôt confuse the end user, and is more intuitive since you‚Äôre using design elements of the app that already exist, which minimizes the new feature learning curve.(Assuming we‚Äôre on the lower end of the size and scale of group chats, which i‚Äôd assume are more common than larger ones.)

On the other hand, our greater problem is going to be the amount of indicators. With large group chats, it‚Äôs going to be quite a challenge to condense the amount of visible indication for these read receipts while keeping it usable.

I‚Äôd love to hear more of what you think here. Thank you to all who‚Äôve replied so far, hopefully this idea gets some serious traction on the road to implementation, hopefully.

RequestForChange:

how large signal group chats are

There is no hard limit. In practice there are performance-limitations, things are fine with a couple dozen groupchat-participants, if you get above fifty groupchat-participants at least some people have reported some slowness-but-not-unusably-slow, and I am not aware of anybody attempting many hundreds (let alone many thousands) of participants. But signalapp groupchats are purely client-side, so the server does not ‚Äúknow‚Äù at the protocol level how many groupchats there even are, let alone what size-distribution-curve there is. Timing-analysis could figure that out by deduction, but network-logs are kept in RAM server-side and then deleted when they have served their purpose, is my understanding.

That said, it is fair to say that signalapp is not concentrating on massive groupchats, thus far at least the emphasis has been on smaller friends-n-family type things. That might mean a soccer squad groupchat or a corporate groupchat or a family reunion groupchat or a political-dissident groupchat, my usual example is 99-members, but would not extend to 9-million-member groupchats [yet at least] :-)

link_counts.title: What is the maximum size for a group chat?
Large groups tend to become unusable over time

posts.cooked: Well with that being said, i think this idea would definitely work with the usual applications that most users give to group chats.

posts.name: Hannes
posts.cooked:
Another suggestion to implement this:
How about, when you click on the small read icon, it opens a list of group chat people including their read status, like a small message bubble appearing as a new layer over the chat. This would be enough for small groups I think. For bigger groups, you probably still need to look into the message information.
You mean like an expandable overlay that can be clicked with a scrollable list that pops up from the read receipt icon?

posts.name: Hannes
posts.cooked: Yeah exactly, maybe it doesn‚Äôt even need to be scrollable. Just a list of maybe 5-7 people, and if there are more in the group, just say ‚Äúand x more‚Äù at the bottom of the list. This way it wouldnt be too bloated. For larger groups the list could maybe be expanded somehow by another tap on the screen.

Right now what happens is like this:

  • longpress on message
  • hit the message-details icon in the titlebar
  • see table of groupchat-members (not possible to sort it) plus checkmarks to the righthand side indicating whether the person‚Äôs device has accepted delivery yet with double-unfilled-checkmarks, and additionally whether the person has viewed/read the message by clicking on the groupchat yet using double-filled-checkmarks.

The process is slightly different on signal4desktop‚Ä¶ not sure how it works on signal4ios. What is being suggested, here in this thread, is a way to visually indicate some of that message-details stuff, either right in the metadata-line of the chat-bubble, or possibly, in a small popup which appears above / overlaying the chat-bubbles.

My suggestion would be this, in the context of signal4android:

  • in the metadata-line of every groupchat message chat-bubble, just to the lefthand side of the traditional double-checkmark thing, there should be some numerals which indicate how many people have sent back read-receipts. In a groupchat of 99 participants, where 88 of them have read-receipts enabled, this would say 3/88 for instance. Only once the 88/88 value has been reached, the metadata-line can optionally be collapsed away, to save vertical space in the chat-history.

  • to the lefthand side of the ‚Äú3/88‚Äù indicator, use colored-dot-dominos to display a compact indication of roughly who has read the message in question. To save space, each domino-dot will just be the assigned-per-contact color. However, individuals in the groupchat will ‚Äúalways‚Äù retain their ‚Äòseat at the table‚Äô on the dominos‚Ä¶ if Bob is in the top-righthand corner of the 2nd domino in a particular groupchat, he will always be in that positional spot.

  • longpress on the dominos, should cause a popup to appear which displays a more-detailed view of the dominos, ‚Äòblown up‚Äô in size to be able indicate a thumbnail-avatar-picture. Bob will still be at the same spot on the big-domino rendered in the popup, top-righthand corner of the 2nd big-domino‚Ä¶ but it will be his avatar so his face is visible, with Bob‚Äôs assigned contact-color as the square background-area around the avatar-circle. (This is better than the tiny dominos‚Ä¶ plus mirrors their layout, to aid Alice‚Äôs memory in the future, so she won‚Äôt have to longpress the dominos as often after awhile.) The popup should be something you can swipe to the right and left to scroll around, if necessary.

  • as usual when you longpress on a message, at the top of the screen there will be a titlebar-toolbar that allows you to press on message-details. If you do that, the big-domino-popup closes, and you see the message-details screen with the long list of the members of the groupchat. Ideally, there will be some indication of their domino-position, in the righthand column of the message-details list.

This is a pretty cool setup. We can use a tiny color-dot on the normal chat-bubble, and if Alice has memorized what ‚Äúseat at the table‚Äù certain groupchat members have on the tiny-domino, she can tell at a glance who has read her message and who has not. If she wishes, she can longpress the metadata-line dominos on any chat-bubble, and see an oversized-domino version where every domino-dot is the avatar of the contact in question. And if she needs all the details, she can just tap the usual message-details icon in the titlebar, like signalapp already works.

link_counts.title: Show footers (time, delivery check mark, read check mark) for every message
How do read receipts work in groups?

posts.cooked:
I‚Äôd love to be able to see at a glance each participant‚Äôs latest read receipts. Right now, I have to keep clicking on the ‚Äú‚Ä¶‚Äù option of the latest sent message and manually check who‚Äôs seen it.

An ideal solution would be something like Facebook Messenger‚Äôs floating read receipt profile pictures.

Hi everyone. Sorry for abandoning ship on this thread as life took priority and I honestly forgot to get back to this. I think I have since figured out a rather simple solution to this thread topic.

I think if the devs could figure out how to create a pop-up menu like a square bubble whenever you long press on the message, and have a scrollable list of people who have read the message with their respective checkmarks right next to their name individually that would work best imo.

What does everyone here think?

posts.name: Alan
posts.cooked: You can already long press on a message and hit the ‚Äúi‚Äù and get exactly what you are describing.

i‚Äôm talking about a mechanism similar to 3D touch though. Something a little bit more intuitive and single step. If you‚Äôre in a large group chat it would be tedious to keep checking using the legacy method, but that‚Äôs just my opinion.
Keep in mind those people with older phones that don‚Äôt support 3D touch (myself included)
perhaps you misunderstood what I was saying. I said something similar to 3D touch, not something actually dependent on it. I hope that clears things up.

I think I may have come up with a final version of this idea that would definitely work. All you‚Äôd need to do is use the user‚Äôs profile picture circle and have that be opaque/darkened until they read it, and then the circle is ‚Äúfilled in‚Äù with the original color or a checkmark inside of it.

Simple, intuitive, and wouldn‚Äôt require completely reinventing the wheel. Been thinking about this for a long time, and I think this might be the way to go.

As far as checking the status of it, you could have the same type of popup overlay style box that reactions use but it comes up with all of the message statuses, and a double tap could be what brings it up.

What do you all think?
